abstract: The upconversion detection is a promising method to detect infrared radiation. It is proved that the focused beam makes a contribution to improving the upconversion efficiency. A near-infrared detector at room-temperature based on sum frequency generation(SFG) with focused beams is demonstrated. To enhance the upconversion efficiency, the signal and pump beams are tightly focused by the same focal...
articleTitle: The Dispersion Reduction Frequency Upconversion System at 1550 nm With Tightly Focused Beam

SECTION I.

Introduction

Nowadays, the infrared(IR) detection technology plays an important role in remote sensing. With the advantage of eye safety, the $1.5~\mu m$ laser draws much attention [1]–​[3]. Especially, due to the highest maximum permissible exposure in the wavelength ranging from $0.3 ~\mu m$ to $10 ~\mu m$ and suffering lower atmospheric attenuation, the $1.5~\mu m$ laser is a promising wavelength in active remote sensing such as LiDAR [1], [2], [4], [5]. Normally, the $1.5~\mu m$ signal can be detected by InGaAs detectors directly. Unfortunately, the application of commercial InGaAs detectors are limited by the dark noise and detection efficiency. In contrast, the visible-near infrared detectors such as Si-based detector perform better on overcoming the dark noise at $0.6~\mu m-1.1~\mu m$ .

Currently, the frequency upconversion has became an alternative to infrared detection technology. According to [6], [7], the noise in the frequency upconversion process can be reduce to photon level. Especially, the thermal noise of upconversion process can be neglected at $1.5~\mu m$ [8]. To avoid the dark noise in InGaAs detectors, it is available to use a Si-based detector detect $1.5~\mu m$ signal indirectly after the signal is converted by the frequency upconversion system. The frequency upconversion can be described as a process that the IR signal mixed with a pump field is transferred into corresponding visible/near-IR signal inside a $\chi ^{(2) }$ material [9]. The upconverted signal is detected by visible-near infrared detectors. In the past decade year, there are many researches about frequency upconversion [4], [10]–​[13]. Taking advantage of high peak power of pulse laser, the upconversion efficiency of 64% has been achieved with the average pump power of $28.7mW$ at $17.9MHz$ within the pulse duration of $5.3 ps$ [14]. Benefited from the quasi-phasematch(QPM) technology and the period poled nonlinear crystal such as PPLN, the upconversion efficiency in single-photon counting system can reach approximately 90% [15]. With the application of the waveguide, the PPLN bulk can be replaced by the PPLN-waveguide because these devices have a higher upconversion efficiency. Several researches shows the upconversion efficiency of the PPLN-waveguide is beyond 50% [16], [17]. Unfortunately, a drawback of PPLN-waveguides is more intense parasitic second harmonic generation(SHG) of the pump wavelength can’t be separated easily [18].

Normally, the signal beam is focused but the pump beam is kept collimated in an upconversion system. Then, a dichroic mirror(DM) is applied to combine the signal beam and the pump beam before two beams incident the nonlinear crystal [10], [19]. Besides, it is proved that the signal beam and the pump beam are focused before two beams combined by a dichroic mirror is more effective [14], [20]. Unfortunately, it is hard to apply tightly focusing to enhance the upconversion efficiency because the dichroic mirror is placed between the lens and the nonlinear crystal. To our knowledge, the focal length of the lens that is used to focus the signal beam is more than $100mm$ in terms of existing upconversion systems. Inspired by [21], a polarization maintaining wavelength division multiplexer connected with a collimator is applied to combine the signal pulse and the pump continue-wave beam instead of a dichroic mirror in our system, which contributes to ensuring the signal pulse and the pump beam are collinear. However, with the light transmitting in the fiber, the power of pump light is limited. To overcome that the upconversion efficiency suffers the limited pump power, we use a lens with short focal length focus the mixed beam into the PPLN. To optimize our system, the relation between the focused beam and the upconversion efficiency is investigated. A classic theory with neglecting the dispersion is proposed by Boyd and Kleinman [22] and the theory really contributes to optimizing upconversion systems. Because the phase-mismatch and the interaction between the signal beam and the pump beam in PPLN are not independent on the dispersion, it is still necessary to investigate the influence of dispersion on the relation between the focused beams and the upconversion efficiency. With the help of proposed model, the negative influences of the dispersion is reduced and the result shows the upconversion efficiency can reaches $5.23 \times 10^{-4}$ with the pump power $172mW$ .

SECTION II.

Setup

In this section, the experimental setup is introduced and the schematic drawing is given in Fig (1). To mix the signal pulse with the pump beam, a $1550nm$ pulse laser and a $1950nm$ continue-wave laser are connected with a polarization maintaining wavelength division multiplexer. The mixed beam is output by a collimator connected with the polarization maintaining wavelength division multiplexer and it has a divergence 0.075° with the diameter of $3.2 mm$ . Then, the collimator and two lenses(L1, L2) are installed on a cage system to ensure they are coaxial. We use the lens L1 to focus the mixed beam and the lens L2 to collimate the converted light. The parameter of L2 is the same as L1. The size of L1 and L2 is $\varnothing 1''$ . A 5% MgO doped PPLN bulk is placed in a temperature-controlled device and located on the center of the L1 and L2. The size of PPLN bulk is $20mm$ long, $2mm$ width and $1mm$ high. The poling period is $24.1 ~\mu m$ . One side of the PPLN bulk is coated with an antireflection(AR)-film for high transmission at $1550nm$ and $1950nm$ . Another side is coated with an antireflection(AR)-film for high transmission at $863nm$ . The temperature of PPLN is kept at $58.4\pm 0.1 C^{\circ }$ . A long pass filter at $850nm$ prevents the noise from background. Finally, the generated upconverted light is detected by a PMT.

To investigate the relation of the mixed beam size and the influence of dispersion, an iris diaphragm is inserted between the collimator and L1 to control the radius of the mixed beam output from the collimator. The radius of aperture ranges from $0.5mm$ to $5mm$ . The $1950nm$ continue-wave laser is the source of pump beam and The $1550nm$ pulse laser is the signal source. The pulse duration is $10ns$ and the repetition rate is $10KHz$ . In terms of the PMT, the spectral response of PMT is $300nm 890nm$ , the rise time is $0.78ns$ , the sensitivity is $30mA/W$ and the gain is set to $3 \times 10^{5}$ . With the effective area diameter of the PMT is $7mm$ , all the converted light can be detected.

SECTION III.

Sum Frequency Generation

In our system, the IR signal is converted to near infrared via sum frequency generation(SFG). In SFG, the energy of the pump photon with frequency $\omega _{2}$ is transferred to the signal photon of frequency $\omega _{1}$ in the PPLN bulk. Because of the conservation of energy in the process, the energy of converted photon comes from the signal photon and the pump photon, which means the converted photon frequency $\omega _{3}$ equals \begin{equation*} \omega _{3}= \omega _{1}+ \omega _{2}.\tag{1}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \omega _{3}= \omega _{1}+ \omega _{2}.\tag{1}\end{equation*}

The wave vectors of signal photons, pump photons and converted photons are defined as $\mathbf {k_{1}}$ , $\mathbf {k_{2}}$ and $\mathbf {k_{3}}$ separately. Because of the conservation of momentum, the wave vector of the converted signal is shown as Figure (2), which can be expressed as \begin{equation*} \mathbf {k_{3}}=\mathbf {k_{1}}+\mathbf {k_{2}}+\mathbf {G}+\mathbf {\Delta k},\tag{2}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathbf {k_{3}}=\mathbf {k_{1}}+\mathbf {k_{2}}+\mathbf {G}+\mathbf {\Delta k},\tag{2}\end{equation*} where $\mathbf {G}$ stands for the contribution of the nonlinear medium with a quasi-phase-matching periodicity of $\Lambda $ [23] and $\left |{ \mathbf {G} }\right |$ can be written as $\left |{ \mathbf {G} }\right |=2\pi /\Lambda $ . $\mathbf {\Delta k}$ stands for so-called phase-mismatch to describe the upconversion efficiency. To analyze the converted signal, it is necessary to consider the minimum phase-mismatch in our system. According to (2), it is known that since $\left |{ \mathbf {G} }\right |$ only varies with the temperature, the direction of $\mathbf {k_{3}}$ and $\mathbf {\Delta k}$ depends on the $\mathbf {k_{1}}$ and $\mathbf {k_{2}}$ . From [24], we can deduce that $\mathbf {k_{3}}$ and $\mathbf {\Delta k}$ are a group of collinear vectors with opposite direction. In our system, with the signal beam and the pump beam focused into PPLN, there is a possibility that the signal photon interacts with a pump photon while corresponding $\mathbf {k_{1}}$ and $\mathbf {k_{2}}$ are not on the same plane. Using spherical coordinates $\theta _{i}, \varphi _{i} (i=1,2)$ , the phase-mismatch for any $\mathbf {k_{1}}$ depends on \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2}+\mathbf {G}=(\mathbf {k_{3}}-\mathbf {\Delta k})cos\theta _{3}\\ \mathbf {k_{1}}sin\theta _{1}cos\varphi _{1}\!+\!\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2}cos\varphi _{2}=(\mathbf {k_{3}}\!-\!\mathbf {\Delta k})sin\theta _{3}cos\varphi _{3}\\ \mathbf {k_{1}}sin\theta _{1}sin\varphi _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}sin\theta _{2}cos\varphi _{2}=(\mathbf {k_{3}}\!-\!\mathbf {\Delta k})sin\theta _{3}sin\varphi _{3}. \end{cases}\tag{3}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2}+\mathbf {G}=(\mathbf {k_{3}}-\mathbf {\Delta k})cos\theta _{3}\\ \mathbf {k_{1}}sin\theta _{1}cos\varphi _{1}\!+\!\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2}cos\varphi _{2}=(\mathbf {k_{3}}\!-\!\mathbf {\Delta k})sin\theta _{3}cos\varphi _{3}\\ \mathbf {k_{1}}sin\theta _{1}sin\varphi _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}sin\theta _{2}cos\varphi _{2}=(\mathbf {k_{3}}\!-\!\mathbf {\Delta k})sin\theta _{3}sin\varphi _{3}. \end{cases}\tag{3}\end{align*}

In frequency upconversion, producing an output signal efficiently need a certain phase-matching condition, which indicates the $\mathbf {\left |{ \Delta k }\right |}$ is smaller than $\mathbf {\left |{ k_{i} }\right |} (i=1,2,3)$ . On this condition, the $\mathbf {\left |{ \Delta k }\right |}$ is calculated as \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |=\mathbf {k_{3}} - \sqrt {\mathbf {k_{1}}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{2}}^{2}+\mathbf {G}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{12}}+\mathbf {k_{12G}}}\\ \mathbf {k_{12}}=2\mathbf {k_{1}}\mathbf {k_{2}}[sin\theta _{1}sin\theta _{2}cos(\varphi _{1}-\varphi _{2})+cos\theta _{1}cos\theta _{2}]\\ \mathbf {k_{12G}}=2\mathbf {G}(\mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2}), \end{cases}\tag{4}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |=\mathbf {k_{3}} - \sqrt {\mathbf {k_{1}}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{2}}^{2}+\mathbf {G}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{12}}+\mathbf {k_{12G}}}\\ \mathbf {k_{12}}=2\mathbf {k_{1}}\mathbf {k_{2}}[sin\theta _{1}sin\theta _{2}cos(\varphi _{1}-\varphi _{2})+cos\theta _{1}cos\theta _{2}]\\ \mathbf {k_{12G}}=2\mathbf {G}(\mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2}), \end{cases}\tag{4}\end{align*} where $\left |{ \mathbf {k} }\right |=n_{i}\omega _{i}/c (i=1,2,3)$ , $n_{i}$ is the refraction index of wavelength $\lambda _{i} $ in nonlinear crystals and $c$ is the light speed in vacuum. From (4), we can deduce that all the vectors are on the same plane is one of the condition that $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |$ reaches the minimum. When all the vectors are on a plane, $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |$ can be simplified to \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |=\mathbf {k_{3}} - \sqrt {\mathbf {k_{1}}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{2}}^{2}+\mathbf {G}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{12}}+\mathbf {k_{12G}}}\\ \mathbf {k_{12}}=2\mathbf {G}(\mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2})\\ \mathbf {k_{12G}}=2\mathbf {k_{1}}\mathbf {k_{2}}cos(\theta _{1}-\theta _{2}), \end{cases}\tag{5}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |=\mathbf {k_{3}} - \sqrt {\mathbf {k_{1}}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{2}}^{2}+\mathbf {G}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{12}}+\mathbf {k_{12G}}}\\ \mathbf {k_{12}}=2\mathbf {G}(\mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2})\\ \mathbf {k_{12G}}=2\mathbf {k_{1}}\mathbf {k_{2}}cos(\theta _{1}-\theta _{2}), \end{cases}\tag{5}\end{align*}

Equation (5) shows a smaller $\left |{ \theta _{1}-\theta _{2} }\right |$ makes a contribution to a certain phase-matching condition. Especially, $\theta _{1}=\theta _{2}=0$ is another condition that makes $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |$ reach the minimum.

Reference to [25], the $\eta $ is given by \begin{equation*} \eta =\frac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}I_{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\frac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)\tag{6}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \eta =\frac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}I_{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\frac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)\tag{6}\end{equation*} where $I_{2}$ is the intensity of $\omega _{2}$ . $L$ is the interaction length of input waves of frequency $\omega _{1}$ and $\omega _{2}$ in the PPLN. $d_{eff}$ is the effective nonlinear coefficient of the PPLN. $\varepsilon _{0}$ is the vacuum permeability. Here, the upconversion efficiency depends on $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |$ when the pump power and the nonlinear crystal are set up. Consequently, the total upconversion efficiency can be written as a function about $\theta _{1}$ and $\theta _{2}$ .

SECTION IV.

Upconversion Model

To enhance the upconversion efficiency with limited pump power, the tightly focusing is applied. Hence, it is necessary to investigate the relation between the focused beams and the upconversion efficiency. A simplified model is proposed to describe it. Especially, the focal length shift caused by the dispersion of lens L1 should not be neglected in this model. The model is based on the assumption that the beam size of both the signal and the pump can be approximated to $w_{0}$ and the signal beam is focused into the center of nonlinear medium. With spherical coordinates $\theta _{i}, \varphi _{i} (i=1,2)$ , the total power of converted light $P_{3}$ can be expressed by a double integral over the incident angles. The $P_{3}$ is \begin{equation*} P_{3}=\int _{0}^{2\pi }\int _{0}^{\theta _{max}}CI_{1}I_{2} sin\theta _{1}sin\theta _{2} d\theta _{1} d\theta _{2} d\varphi _{1} d\varphi _{2},\tag{7}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} P_{3}=\int _{0}^{2\pi }\int _{0}^{\theta _{max}}CI_{1}I_{2} sin\theta _{1}sin\theta _{2} d\theta _{1} d\theta _{2} d\varphi _{1} d\varphi _{2},\tag{7}\end{equation*} where $C$ stands for the upconversion efficiency corresponding to a pair of wave vectors $\mathbf {k_{1}}$ and $\mathbf {k_{2}}$ and can be written to a function $C(\theta _{1},\theta _{2},\varphi _{1},\varphi _{2})$ . $\theta _{max}$ is the maximum incident angle and $I_{i} (i=1,2)$ is the intensity of incident light in the nonlinear crystal. According to (7), the $C(\theta _{1},\theta _{2},\varphi _{1},\varphi _{2})$ is \begin{equation*} C(\theta _{1},\theta _{2},\varphi _{1},\varphi _{2})=\frac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\frac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right).\tag{8}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} C(\theta _{1},\theta _{2},\varphi _{1},\varphi _{2})=\frac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\frac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right).\tag{8}\end{equation*}

In (8), $\mathbf {\Delta k}$ depends on (6). With the upconversion process occurring when the phase-mismatch is the minimum, we can deduce $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |_{min}=\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right | (\theta _{1}-\theta _{2})_{min}$ from (5). In ideal conditions, $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |_{min}=\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |\delta (\theta _{1}-\theta _{2})$ . As a result, (5) can be described as \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |=\mathbf {k_{3}} - \sqrt {\mathbf {k_{1}}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{2}}^{2}+\mathbf {G}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{12}}+\mathbf {k_{12G}}}\\ \mathbf {k_{12}}=2\mathbf {G}(\mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2})\\ \mathbf {k_{12G}}=2\mathbf {k_{1}}\mathbf {k_{2}}cos(\theta _{1}-\theta _{2})\\ \theta _{2}=argmin(\theta _{1}-\theta _{2}). \end{cases}\tag{9}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |=\mathbf {k_{3}} - \sqrt {\mathbf {k_{1}}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{2}}^{2}+\mathbf {G}^{2}+\mathbf {k_{12}}+\mathbf {k_{12G}}}\\ \mathbf {k_{12}}=2\mathbf {G}(\mathbf {k_{1}}cos\theta _{1}+\mathbf {k_{2}}cos\theta _{2})\\ \mathbf {k_{12G}}=2\mathbf {k_{1}}\mathbf {k_{2}}cos(\theta _{1}-\theta _{2})\\ \theta _{2}=argmin(\theta _{1}-\theta _{2}). \end{cases}\tag{9}\end{align*}

(9) shows the expression $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |$ exists when $\theta _{1}-\theta _{2}$ is minimum. Considering the focal length shift caused by the dispersion of the lens L1, the mixed beam consisting of the signal and pump beams separates in PPLN. As a result, the phase-mismatch depends on the propagation of two beams.

According to the coordinate shown as Figure (3), $I_{1}I_{2}$ is the central symmetry on the plane $XOY$ and it is independent on $\varphi _{1}$ and $\varphi _{2}$ . The propagation of the signal beam can be described as \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \dfrac {w_{1}(z)^{2}}{w_{1z}^{2}}-\dfrac {(z-L_{l}-L/2)^{2}}{z_{10}^{2}}=1\\ w_{1z}=\dfrac {\lambda _{1}f_{1}}{\pi w_{0}}\\ z_{10}=\sqrt {\dfrac {L}{2}(A-B)}\\ f_{1}=f+\Delta f_{1}\\ A\!=\!\sqrt {(n_{1}^{2}\!-\!1)w_{1z}^{2}\!+\!(n_{1}z_{1l})^{2}\!+\!\left({1\!-\!\dfrac {(2n_{1}z_{1l}/L)^{2}L}{4}}\right)^{2}}\\ B=\dfrac {1-(2n_{1}z_{1l}/L)^{2}L}{4}\\[6pt] L_{l}=f_{1}-\dfrac {z_{1l}L}{2w_{1z}}\\ z_{1l}=\dfrac {f_{1}}{\sqrt {(r0/w_{1z})^{2}-1}}, \end{cases}\tag{10}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \dfrac {w_{1}(z)^{2}}{w_{1z}^{2}}-\dfrac {(z-L_{l}-L/2)^{2}}{z_{10}^{2}}=1\\ w_{1z}=\dfrac {\lambda _{1}f_{1}}{\pi w_{0}}\\ z_{10}=\sqrt {\dfrac {L}{2}(A-B)}\\ f_{1}=f+\Delta f_{1}\\ A\!=\!\sqrt {(n_{1}^{2}\!-\!1)w_{1z}^{2}\!+\!(n_{1}z_{1l})^{2}\!+\!\left({1\!-\!\dfrac {(2n_{1}z_{1l}/L)^{2}L}{4}}\right)^{2}}\\ B=\dfrac {1-(2n_{1}z_{1l}/L)^{2}L}{4}\\[6pt] L_{l}=f_{1}-\dfrac {z_{1l}L}{2w_{1z}}\\ z_{1l}=\dfrac {f_{1}}{\sqrt {(r0/w_{1z})^{2}-1}}, \end{cases}\tag{10}\end{align*} where $L_{l}$ is the distance from the lens L1 to the front face of PPLN bulk. Especially, $f$ is the given focal length of lens L1 and $\Delta f_{1}$ is the focal length shift of the lens L1 at $\lambda _{1}$ relative to $f$ . $w_{1}(z)$ stands for the signal beam size in the PPLN with $z$ varying from $L_{l}$ to $L+L_{l}$ . Then, the maximum incident angle at $\lambda _{1}$ is $arctan(w_{1z}/z_{10})$ . Once $L_{l}$ is determined, the propagation of the pump beam can be expressed as \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \dfrac {w_{2}(z)^{2}}{w_{2z}^{2}}-\dfrac {(z-L_{l}-L_{2})^{2}}{z_{20}^{2}}=1\\ w_{2z}=\dfrac {\lambda _{2}f_{2}}{\pi w_{0}}\\ z_{20}=\sqrt {(n_{2}z_{2l})^{2}+(n_{2}^{2}-1)w_{2z}^{2}/\left({1+\left({\dfrac {z_{2l}}{L_{l}-f_{2}}}\right)^{2}}\right)}\\ z_{2l}=\dfrac {f_{2}}{\sqrt {(r0/w_{2z})^{2}-1}}\\ L_{2}=\dfrac {(z_{2l}-z_{20})L_{l}+z_{20}f_{2}}{z_{2l}}-L_{l}\\ f_{2}=f+\Delta f_{2} \end{cases}\tag{11}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \dfrac {w_{2}(z)^{2}}{w_{2z}^{2}}-\dfrac {(z-L_{l}-L_{2})^{2}}{z_{20}^{2}}=1\\ w_{2z}=\dfrac {\lambda _{2}f_{2}}{\pi w_{0}}\\ z_{20}=\sqrt {(n_{2}z_{2l})^{2}+(n_{2}^{2}-1)w_{2z}^{2}/\left({1+\left({\dfrac {z_{2l}}{L_{l}-f_{2}}}\right)^{2}}\right)}\\ z_{2l}=\dfrac {f_{2}}{\sqrt {(r0/w_{2z})^{2}-1}}\\ L_{2}=\dfrac {(z_{2l}-z_{20})L_{l}+z_{20}f_{2}}{z_{2l}}-L_{l}\\ f_{2}=f+\Delta f_{2} \end{cases}\tag{11}\end{align*} where $L_{2}$ is the distance from the front face of the PPLN bulk to the minimum size of the pump beam in the PPLN. $\Delta f_{2}$ is the focal length shift of the lens L1 at $\lambda _{2}$ relative to $f$ . Similar to $w_{1}(z)$ , $w_{2}(z)$ stands for the pump beam size in the PPLN with $z$ varying from $L_{l}$ to $L+L_{l}$ . To reduce the phase-mismatch, $(\theta _{1}-\theta _{2})_{min}$ can be rewritten as \begin{equation*} \theta _{1}-\theta _{2}=\theta _{1}[1-arctan(z-L_{l})/L_{2}].\tag{12}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \theta _{1}-\theta _{2}=\theta _{1}[1-arctan(z-L_{l})/L_{2}].\tag{12}\end{equation*}

Since the focal length shift leads that $w_{1}(z)$ does not equal $w_{2}(z)$ for every $z \in [L_{l},L+L_{l}]$ , it is necessary to use a coefficient $\eta _{sp}(z)$ to describe the interaction between the signal beam and the pump beam. When both the signal beam and the pump beam enter the nonlinear crystal, $\eta _{sp}(z)$ depends on the area of the signal beam overlapping the pump beam and $\eta _{sp}(z)$ can be expressed as \begin{equation*} \eta _{sp}(z)=[min(w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z))/max(w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z))]^{2}\tag{13}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \eta _{sp}(z)=[min(w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z))/max(w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z))]^{2}\tag{13}\end{equation*}

$\eta _{sp}(z)$ limits the power of the signal beam and the pump beam in upconversion process. What’s more, $\eta _{sp}(z)$ , $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$ vary with the propagation distance in the nonlinear crystal. $P_{3}$ is an integer alone $z$ axis from $z \in [L_{l},L+L_{l}]$ . Then, (7) is rewritten as \begin{align*} \begin{cases} P_{3}=\int _{L_{l}}^{L+L_{l}}\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{2\pi }\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{\theta _{max}} CI_{1}I_{2}\\ \qquad \times \sin \theta _{1}sin\theta _{2} d\theta _{1} d\theta _{2} d\varphi _{1} d\varphi _{2}dz\\ I_{1}I_{2}=\dfrac {P_{1}P_{2}}{(\pi w_{1}(z)w_{2}(z))^{2}}\eta _{sp}(z), \end{cases}\tag{14}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} P_{3}=\int _{L_{l}}^{L+L_{l}}\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{2\pi }\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{\theta _{max}} CI_{1}I_{2}\\ \qquad \times \sin \theta _{1}sin\theta _{2} d\theta _{1} d\theta _{2} d\varphi _{1} d\varphi _{2}dz\\ I_{1}I_{2}=\dfrac {P_{1}P_{2}}{(\pi w_{1}(z)w_{2}(z))^{2}}\eta _{sp}(z), \end{cases}\tag{14}\end{align*}

According to (5), the phase-match becomes independent on $\varphi _{i}(i=1,2)$ . (12) shows $\theta _{2}$ is relevant to $\theta _{1}$ . $C(\theta _{1},\theta _{2},\varphi _{1},\varphi _{2})$ can be simplified to $C(\theta _{1})$ . Additional, the power mainly concentrates on the facula center nearby and the converted light is generated in the area. So the corresponding beam size is smaller than the sport sizes. On this condition, the area within beam size can be approximated to average distribution. Neglecting the loss in propagation, the intensity of the signal beam and the pump beam are $I_{i}(z)=\frac {P_{i}}{\pi w_{i}(z)^{2}}(i=1,2)$ , which is irrelevant to $\varphi _{i}(i=1,2)$ . The integral reduces to \begin{align*} \begin{cases} P_{3}=2\pi \displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{L}\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{\theta _{max}}C(\theta _{1})P_{in}(z-L_{l})\\ \qquad \times \sin \theta _{1}cos\theta _{2}(\theta _{1}) d\theta _{1}dz\\ C(\theta _{1})=\dfrac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\dfrac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)\\ P_{in}'(z) =\dfrac {P_{1}P_{2}}{(\pi w_{1}(z)w_{2}(z))^{2}}\eta _{sp}(z). \end{cases}\tag{15}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} P_{3}=2\pi \displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{L}\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{\theta _{max}}C(\theta _{1})P_{in}(z-L_{l})\\ \qquad \times \sin \theta _{1}cos\theta _{2}(\theta _{1}) d\theta _{1}dz\\ C(\theta _{1})=\dfrac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\dfrac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)\\ P_{in}'(z) =\dfrac {P_{1}P_{2}}{(\pi w_{1}(z)w_{2}(z))^{2}}\eta _{sp}(z). \end{cases}\tag{15}\end{align*}

In (15), $\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |$ depends on (5) and (12). According to the definition of upconversion efficiency, the total upconversion efficiency $\eta _{tot}$ is \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \eta _{tot}=2\pi \displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{L}\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{\theta _{max}}C(\theta _{1})P_{in}(z-L_{l})\\ \qquad \times sin\theta _{1}cos\theta _{2}(\theta _{1}) d\theta _{1}dz\\ C(\theta _{1})=\dfrac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\dfrac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)\\ P_{in}(z) =\dfrac {P_{2}}{(\pi w_{1}(z)w_{2}(z))^{2}}\eta _{sp}(z). \end{cases}\tag{16}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \eta _{tot}=2\pi \displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{L}\displaystyle \int \nolimits _{0}^{\theta _{max}}C(\theta _{1})P_{in}(z-L_{l})\\ \qquad \times sin\theta _{1}cos\theta _{2}(\theta _{1}) d\theta _{1}dz\\ C(\theta _{1})=\dfrac {8\pi ^{2}d_{eff}^{2}L^{2}}{n_{1}n_{2}n_{3}\varepsilon _{0}c\lambda _{3}^{2}}sinc^{2}\left({\dfrac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)\\ P_{in}(z) =\dfrac {P_{2}}{(\pi w_{1}(z)w_{2}(z))^{2}}\eta _{sp}(z). \end{cases}\tag{16}\end{align*}

Here, $P_{in}(z)$ stands for the available power of the pump beam for upconversion process. It is essential to remind that (16) is based on conditions as follows. Firstly, the signal beam is focused into the center of the nonlinear medium. Secondly, the size of the signal beam and the pump beam on the nonlinear crystal front face are not larger than the size of nonlinear crystal, which means $max(w_{1}(L_{l}),w_{2}(L_{l})) \leq d/2$ , where $d$ is the thickness of the nonlinear crystal. At the end, all the converted light should be recorded by the detector.

A. The Influence of Dispersion

With the dispersion existing, the focal length $f$ of lens L1 shifts according to the wavelength. To describe the difference of the focal length between the signal beam and the pump beam, the focal length shift of lens L1 is defined as $\Delta f_{i}(i=1,2)$ . In proposed model, $f$ influences the size of both the signal beam and the pump beam in the nonlinear crystal. The interaction of two beams depends on $\Delta f_{i}(i=1,2)$ in some degree. In terms of the size of two beams, because it is hard to measure the beam size in the PPLN bulk, a simulation is used to analyze $w_{i}(z)(i=1,2)$ on $[L_{l},L+L_{l}]$ instead of measuring directly. To show the influence of the dispersion, another group of lenses are used to display $w_{i}(z)(i=1,2)$ when the dispersion becomes serious. The simulation was finished in ZEMAX and the result is shown as fig (4).

On the other hand, the phase-match plays an important role in upconversion. According to (5) and (16), the phase-match depends on the incident angle, but the existing of the dispersion makes the phase-match varies alone $z$ . To minimize phase-mismatch, the $k_{1}$ , $k_{2}$ and $G$ should be collinear, which means the incident angle equals zero and the maximum value of the phase-match term $sinc^{2}\left({\frac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)$ remain unchanged. Correspondingly, the minimum value of the phase-match term appears when the incident angle is maximum. The Fig (6) shows the phase-match term $sinc^{2}\left({\frac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)$ with two groups of lenses.

Combining the effect of the dispersion on $\eta _{sp}(z)$ and phase-match term$sinc^{2}\left({\frac {\left |{ \mathbf {\Delta k} }\right |L}{2}}\right)$ , we can draw a conclusion that although the tightly focusing is beneficial for enhance the intensity of incident beam and improve the upconversion efficiency, it is affected by the dispersion easily. On the contrast, it is useful to restrain the influence of the dispersion that the signal beam and the pump beam are focused by lens with long focal length.

B. Upconversion Efficiency

An important aspect of an upconversion system is the upconversion efficiency. Here, to show the influence of the dispersion on the upconversion efficiency, two groups of lenses group A and group B inferred from fig (4) are applied in the experiment. The the result are shown as fig (7).

In fig (7), the focal length shift of lenses in group B are larger than group A, but the loss of upconversion with loosely focusing is less than tightly focusing. Comparing the data of two groups, with $\Delta f$ increasing 34.42%, 25.27%, 31.2% and 35.18%, the $\eta _{tot}$ decreases 24.62%, 17.68%, 13.96% and 11.46% corresponding to $f=35mm$ , $f=50mm$ , $f=75mm$ and $f=100mm$ in the experiment. Here are two reasons for the result. Firstly, the dispersion makes the signal beam and the pump beam separate and decreases the interaction area of two beams, which limits the available power of the signal beam and the pump beam in the upconversion process, especially when $w_{i}(z)_{min}(i=1,2)$ . Secondly, with $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ larger than $G$ , the smaller angle between $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ makes a contribution to reducing phase-mismatch. Although the method that both the signal beam and the pump beam are focused into the PPLN can reduce the angle between $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ , the tightly focusing increases the incident angle. When $\theta _{1}$ and $\theta _{2}$ are not too large to make $\mathbf {k_{3}} \gg \mathbf {k_{1}}+\mathbf {k_{2}}+\mathbf {G}$ , the phase-mismatch can be approximated to a constant. However, on the one hand, the tightly focusing makes that the incident angle $\theta _{1}$ and $\theta _{2}$ are larger. On the other hand, it increases the angle $\theta _{1}-\theta _{2}$ , which makes the loss of upconversion efficiency caused by the tightly focusing is more serious.

Furthermore, as the tightly focusing structure has an effect on the incident angle of the signal beam and the pump beam becoming large, it is necessary to take the beam size into consideration. The upconversion efficiency with different beam size is measured and the experimental data are shown as fig (8).

With the help of proposed model, the setup is designed and shown as fig (1). To measure the upconversion efficiency of our system, the iris diaphragm is removed. Because the mixed beam that is output by a collimator connected with PMWDM has a divergence within 0.075° with a diameter of $3.2 mm$ , our system reaches maximum upconversion efficiency on condition that L1 and L2 are achromatic lenses with $f=35mm$ and $\Delta f=0.29mm$ according to fig (8d). To avoid the damage of the PMWDM, the pump power is limited. Measured by the thermal power sensors, the maximum available pump power is $172mW$ . We record data on condition that the output of 1550nm laser is attenuated and the peak power of the signal pulse is $3.87mW$ at 10KHz with pulse duration of $10ns$ . The result is shown as fig (9) and the maximum upconversion efficiency reaches $5.23 \times 10^{-4}$ .

SECTION VI.

Conclusion

In this paper, a dispersion reduction frequency upconversion setup with a tightly focusing is presented. The system transfers light at $1550nm$ to $863nm$ and records the converted signal by a multialkali photocathode PMT. With the help of the polarization selective of single mode polarization-maintaining fiber, the noise is reduced. To enhance the upconversion efficiency with low pump power, the tightly focusing is applied. Benefited from the tightly focusing by a lens with the focal length of $35mm$ , the signal is converted by a pump beam with only $172mW$ . With the help of proposed model, it is revealed that the relation between the focused beam and the upconversion efficiency, which contributes to reduce the influence of the dispersion. The model shows although the tightly focusing makes a contribution to upconversion efficiency, the dispersion has more negative influence on upconversion efficiency when the incident beams are tightly focused extremely. Moreover, the experiment shows the incident beam size increasing makes the influence of dispersion more serious. With the help of the model, the best focal length can be selected to improve the tightly focused upconversion system and our system to reach the maximum upconversion efficiency $5.23 \times 10^{-4}$ with the pump power $172mW$ .

Compared to the existing upconversion system whose upconversion efficiency can reach 10-1 level, the upconversion efficiency of our system can only reach 10-4 level mainly due to the limited of the pump power. Normally, the pump power is more than dozens of watt level while the pump power is only $172mW$ in our system. To avoid combining the signal beam and the pump beam without keep both beams collinear accurately, we have to use a PMWDM to avoid that there is a angle between both beams. However, due to the fiber of the PMWDM cannot suffer the input power more than $300mW$ ,the output of pump source should be less than $300mW$ . Besides, considering the loss of fiber coupling between the pump laser and the PMWDM is 40%, the pump power is less than $180mW$ . Fortunately, with the limited pump power, the back conversion is reduced. To improve our system, a dichroic mirror can be used to replace PMWDM to combine the signal beam and the pump beam on condition that both beams is kept collinear accurately. In this way, the higher pump power can be set without considering the damage threshold of the PMWDM. In the end, the proposed model can make a contribution to reducing the influence of the dispersion in tightly focusing upconversion systems by choosing a reasonable focal length and beam size.
